Prins Laboratory for Technical Chemistry, Eidgensische Technische Hochschule, 8092 Zurich, Switzerland Received 6 March 1995; revised 23 April 1995; accepted 29 April 1995 Abstract Active and stable mordenite catalysts have been developed for the selective nitrobenzene production by vapour-phase nitration of benzene with 65 wt.-% HN03 at normal pressure and 443 K. The acidic and textural properties of commercial synthetic mordenite have been modified by different combinations of thermal and acid treatments. The physico-chemical properties of the catalysts were investigated by Z' Al and 29Si MAS-NMR, AAS, XRD, NZ and low pressure Ar adsorption. The catalytic activity and stability of the modified mordenite catalysts were strongly influenced by the amount and state of aluminium in the zeolite. Extra-framework aluminium species generated by thermal treatment at higher temperatures ( > 973 K) induced a severe catalyst deactivation. The deactivation could almost be eliminated by subsequent acid leaching with 6 N HCI, which removed the extra-framework aluminium to a large extent, thus unblocking the pores and/or pore mouths. An optimum mordenite modification procedure was developed, resulting in highly active and selective catalysts, which retained their initial activity for at least 120 h on stream. Keywords: Mordenite; Dealumination; Catalyst; Benzene; Nitration; Nitrobenzene 1. Introduction For more than a century nitrobenzene has been industrially produced by the nitration of benzene. Nitrobenzene, an important intermediate in the chemical industry, is principally converted into 4,4'-diphenylmethane diisocyanate, which is used for the production of polyurethane. Traditionally, nitration is carried out in continuous isothermal or adiabatic plants, by reacting benzene with `mixed acid' under vigorous agitation, and the conversion of benzene is usually 98% or more. The latter acts as a catalyst (formation of the active electrophilic species NOz ) and binds the water formed during the reaction. Concentrated sulphuric acid in a molar acid to benzene ratio close to unity (isothermal units) or larger (adiabatic units) is required by the process [ 1 ] . After reaction, spent sulfuric acid must be reconcentrated, which leads to corrosion problems, or neutralized, with inherent waste sulfate problems. Nitrophenolic compounds formed as by-products in the mixed acid process are highly toxic and cannot be processed by standard biological treatment because of their bactericidal properties. Traditionally nitrophenols are extracted with benzene and incinerated, which causes safety problems due to their thermal instability. Nitration of benzene in the vapour phase on zeolites would be an interesting alternative to the mixed acid process, since it avoids the use of sulfuric acid. Mordenite is a well known high-silica zeolite which has found wide application in the oil industry, mainly in the field of hydroisomerization, hydrocracking and dewaxing. One of the most interesting features of mordenite is that it can be dealuminated by several methods without critical damage to the structure, leading to a family of highly crystalline materials with tailored acidic and textural properties. The catalytic performance of modified mordenite for a particular application strongly depends on the preparation procedure, since factors like the presence of extra-framework aluminium or the formation of mesoporosity may play an important role, in addition to the framework aluminium content determining the acidity of the material. The use of the large pore zeolite mordenite as a catalyst for the vapour-phase nitration of benzene has so far been reported with commercial acidic materials such as Zeolon 900H, of the Norton Company [ 2,3 ] . However, this catalyst was found to deactivate rapidly in the first few hours on stream, reaching a rather low activity corresponding to a nitrobenzene space time yield of 0.03 g/g cat h after 20 hours. The aim of the present work is to improve the performance of synthetic mordenite for the vapour-phase nitration of benzene by specific modification, using a combination of thermal and acid treatments. The acidic and textural properties of commercial synthetic Na-mordenite have thus been gradually modified, and aluminium was removed from the zeolite framework by different methods, in order to tailor the catalytic properties of mordenite. 2. Since the last two steps in the preparation of both catalysts were exactly the same, calcination at 973 K (5 h) and subsequent leaching with 6 N HCl (16 h), the large difference in the resulting Si/Al ratios of HM37 and HM23 must be due to the Si/Al ratios of 59 and 6 of the precursors HM35 and HM21, respectively. On the other hand, the sodium content may also influence the extent of dealumination, as Chen and Smith [9] found that only H-mordenite is thermally dealuminated while Na-mordenite is not, and Bodart et al. [ 10] observed that dealumination increases with decreasing residual sodium content. However, the influence of sodium in the dealumination of HM36 and HM22 can be ruled out, since sodium was below the detection limit in both cases, and if traces of residual sodium would have been present it would be rather in HM22, since 5 treatments with 1 N resp. 6 N HCl were applied for the preparation of HM36. Furthermore, the effect of sodium on HM22 would be opposite, resulting in a lower Si/Al ratio in HM23 compared with HM37. The results indicate that mordenite dealumination depends not only on the dealuminating conditions, but also on the aluminium content in the precursor. Thus, the higher the aluminium content in a mordenite sample, the more aluminium will be removed by a thermal and acid treatment at a given temperature above about 873 K and at an acid concentration sufficiently high to remove the non structural A1 species which are formed upon the thermal treatment. 3.2. Textural properties of the catalysts The results of the low pressure argon adsorption measurements are presented in Table 1. Changes in the textural properties of mordenite upon the different acid and combined acid and thermal treatments can be monitored by analyzing the porosity (micropore volume) and the surface area (total BET and ESA) of the different samples. BET data reflect both changes in the free micropore area and the L. Bertea et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 129 (1995) 229-250 235 development of mesoporous regions in the catalyst. Since both effects tend to counteract each other, it is difficult to interprete variations of BET surface areas in dealuminated zeolite samples. Apart from the starting sodium mordenite PM 1-Na, the total measured BET surface areas listed in Table 1 are all between 460 and 510 m2/g. The significantly lower BET surface area of PM1-Na is probably due to partial blocking of the side pockets of the main channels by sodium ions, and to the presence of some amorphous silica from the original synthesis in the pores or at the pore mouths, in accordance with the relatively high ESA found in the starting material [ 11 ] . Data determined using the t-plot method, i.e. the micropore volume and the extra-zeolitic surface area (ESA) of the catalysts, are far more sensitive to small structural changes and allow better correlations with the results obtained by other experimental techniques. The method usually applied for the determination of zeolite crystallinity is based on Xmeasurements, and consists in dividing the sum of several specific peak intensities by the respective sum found for a well crystallized sample measured under the same conditions. However, in addition to the relatively high experimental inaccuracy of the method (about 10%) , it does not take into account pore blocking. Since the latter is an important factor in catalytic zeolite applications, it is probably more useful to employ the micropore volume obtained from nitrogen or argon adsorption data and the t-plot method. By assigning an effective mordenite micropore volume of 100% to a value of 0.21 cm'/g, which is the total void volume of mordenite (both 12-and staggered 8-membered rings channels) as calculated by Breck and Grose [ 12 ] from crystallographical data, the modified mordenite samples listed in Table 2 have relative micropore volumes between 80 and 98%. Although the BET surface areas did not show a definite trend with the treatment applied, when the ESA values were subtracted from the BET values, the resulting BET - ESA values displayed exactly the same trend as the micropore volumes shown in Table 1. This is understandable, since during the BET measurement the zeolite pores will be completely filled, and a pore volume rather than a surface area is measured. The BET measurement thus gives the sum of the micropore volume (expressed in terms of surface area) and the surface area of the mesopores. Acid leaching induced in all cases a decrease of the micropore volume, which depended on the acid concentration as well as on the aluminium content of the sample. The micropore volumes of HMI 1 and HM21, which were exchanged once with 1 N HCl during 1 h, were equal to that of HM31 (0.20 cm3/g), which was exchanged three times at the same conditions. However, a substantial decrease of the micropore volume was observed with 6 N HCl (HM31 1 versus HM31) ,owing to the deeper aluminium removal from tetrahedral lattice positions in the sample exposed to the higher HCl concentration, as shown by the Si/Al ratios in Table 1. Similarly, a strong decrease of the micropore volume upon leaching with 6 N HCl was observed if the preceding step was a high temperature treatment on a sample with a low Si/Al ratio, which produces a large amount of nonstructural aluminium (HM23 versus HM31 1) . The fact that the acid leaching induced in all cases (HM12 - HM13; HM22 - HM23; HM32 - HM33; HM34 - HM35; HM36 - HM37; HM31 - HM31 1; and HM311 - HM312) a decrease of the micropore volume suggests that the decrease is brought about by one common cause. This cannot be leaching of the nonstructural aluminium from the pores, or removal of aluminium from the zeolite framework and concomitant leaching from the pores, because in that case the micropore volume should have increased. A possible explanation could be that a partial collapse of the zeolite structure occurs, with concomitant loss or blockage of micropores, or that fissures occur in the zeolite crystals along micropores. In the latter case the micropore volume would diminish and the external surface area would increase, as observed in all six cases in which acid leaching was applied. The temperature of the thermal treatment has a significant influence on the micropore volume of the resulting samples. Up to 773-823 K the micropore volume of high aluminium containing samples (HM 11, HM21, HM31) remained almost constant at high values around 0.20 cm3/g, thus very close to the theoretical maximum value of 0.21 cm3/g. Calcination of mordenite at 923 K might be considered as a mild thermal dealumination, since although aluminium is removed from the structure (as shown by the 29Si NMR results, vide infra), no significant difference in the micropore volume was observed between HM31 and HM32. A thermal treatment at or above 973 K (severe thermal dealumination) induced a stronger decrease of the micropore volume in HM22 and HM 12, even at an already low aluminium content in the precursor, as shown in the case of HM36. The increase of the extra-zeolitic surface area (ESA) upon the different dealumination procedures reflects the formation of mesopores with diameters of about 5 nm in the heat and acid dealuminated samples together with some larger cavities with diameters above 10 nn in the samples dealuminated with 6 N HCl alone, as determined from mesopore size distributions, calculated using the BJH method [ 13 ] on nitrogen desorption data measured at 77.3 K in liquid nitrogen. The development of mesoporous regions in mordenite upon thermal and acid and thermal dealumination derives primarily from the presence of so-called `hydroxyl nests' [ 14], which are formed during the hydrolysis of Al-O bonds in the zeolite framework. Such OH-groups have been reported to be unstable at temperatures above 373 K, since no `hydroxyl nests' are observed at 473 K [ 15 ] . At high temperature structural defects created upon A1 extraction are partially repaired by recrystallization processes, creating mesopores in adjacent regions [ 16] . Extra-zeolitic surface area in mesopores is thus formed at the cost of the micropore volume upon aluminium extraction, to an extent depending on the dealumination conditions, as shown in Fig. 2. The catalysts prepared by calcining HM21 at 973 K and leaching the product with 6 N HCl show a linear relationship between the ESA and the micropore volume. The loss of micropore volume and the gain in extra-zeolitic surface area are large, owing to the drastic conditions applied during the first step on a high aluminium containing sample such as HM21. The samples dealuminated by mere acid treatment with 1 N resp. 6 N HCl (HM31, HM31 1 and HM312) are on the same line as those of the HM21 series, but do not reach the same maximum ESA, since no calcination at 973 K was carried out. On the other hand, calcination or acid leaching on samples with an already low A1 content such as HM35 (Si/Al=59) did not result in an increase of the ESA, probably due to recrystallization processes in the A1 deficient structure of HM36, as confirmed by a slight increase of the unit cell volume going from HM36 to HM33 (vide infra). 3.3. XRD measurements The XRD spectra of all mordenite samples indicated that no phase transformation had occurred during the dealumination procedures. Further, no significant intensity 238 L. Bertea et al. /Applied Catalysis A: General 129 (1995) 229-250 decrease was observed in either of the samples, indicating an XRD crystallinity retainment of 85-90%. The unit cell parameters a, b, c (orthorhombic crystal symmetry) and the unit cell volume of the modified mordenite samples are listed in Table 2. In contrast to zeolite Y, which has a cubic symmetry and thus only one cell parameter which is linearly correlated with the aluminium content [ 17], the unit cell parameters of mordenite vary nonlinearly with the alunium content, as observed by Olson and Rollmann on acid, and heat and acid dealuminated mordenite samples up to an Si/Al ratio of 45 [ 18 ] . A contraction of the unit cell of mordenite up to an Si/Al ratio of about 45 has been reported in several studies [9,19-21 ] as expected owing to the shorter average Si-O (0.162 nm) compared with the Al-O distance (0.175 nm) in zeolites [22]. As shown in Table 2, the unit cell parameters of the modified mordenites prepared in this study decreased upon dealumination up to an Si/Al ratio of about 54 in the heat and acid dealuminated samples (HM34), whereas no further decrease was observed above an Si/Al ratio of 20 (HM311) in the acid dealuminated samples. The unit cell volume of the parent samples HMI1, HM21, HM31 decreased quite rapidly upon aluminium extraction up to a critical Si/Al ratio. This limiting Si / A1 ratio was higher in the samples where dealumination had been carried out by the combination of thermal and acid treatments, as shown by comparing HM34 or HM 12 with HM311. Interestingly, a slight but significant increase of the unit cell volume was observed when HM22, HM34, HM36 (heat and acid dealumination) resp. HM311 (only acid dealumination) were refluxed with 6 N HCI. On the other hand, almost no change of the unit cell was observed when calcining the already highly dealuminated sample HM35 (Si/Al=59) at 973 K, whereas refluxing the product HM36 with 6 N HCl induced again a slight increase of the unit cell volume (HM37). These results suggest that nonstructural Al present in the zeolite pores might reintegrate in tetrahedral framework positions in dealuminated mordenite, as already reported by Hamdan et al. in the case of zeolite Y on the basis of NMR measurements [ 23 ] . An increase of the unit cell volume of dealuminated mordenite under the effect of steam has been observed before [ 11,16] .Dry heat treatment does not induce a reintegration of extra-framework Al (HM35 - HM36; HM33 - HM34) . Successive refluxing with 6 N HCl on the other hand mobilizes oxo/hydroxo extra-framework A1 species. These can either leave the crystallites (high A1 containing zeolite) or be reintegrated in the Al deficient framework of a heat dealuminated zeolite, and therefore increase the unit cell volume (HM36 - HM37; HM34 - HM35). 3.4. Conclusion Dealumination of synthetic mordenite by heat and acid treatments, which drastically reduce the framework as well as the non-framework aluminium content, results in highly active and stable catalysts for the vapour-phase nitration of benzene with 65 wt.-% HN03 at 443 K and atmospheric pressure [31,32]. The modified mordenite catalysts prepared under specific conditions yield nitrobenzene at very high benzene (99.7% + ) and nitric acid (between 80 and 100%) selectivity, while retaining a stable catalytic activity (up to 80% nitrobenzene yield based on HN03 ) during more than 120 h on stream, corresponding to a total nitrobenzene yield of 70 kg/kg catalyst. Within the range of framework Si/Al ratios (6-> 100) investigated by us, catalyst performance increased with the framework Si/Al ratio. Further, it has been shown on the basis of standard physico-chemical methods and catalytic tests that small amounts of non-structural aluminium extracted from the zeolite framework upon thermal treatment above 873 K may restrict the pore system of mordenite and thus hinder the diffusion of dinitrobenzene molecules formed as by-product, resulting in a fast catalytic deactivation within the first hours on stream. The non-framework Al can be removed almost completely from the mordenite pores by leaching with 6 N HCI, provided that the A1 has been thermally extracted from the zeolite framework in subsequent portions at an intermediate calcination temperature of about 923 K.
